Studies show different scenarios of DMS emission changes in response to changing temperature and oceanic pH (Box 3 ), but none have so far examined the potential biochemical and/or functional link between DMS emission and other important VOCs (especially isoprene) in phytoplankton. Cyanobacteria are an important source of marine isoprene in the tropical oceans of today, and there is wide consensus that cyanobacteria will become more prominent in warm oceans. While biochemical competitive constraints on DMSP and DMAPP syntheses remain speculative at this stage, if DMS-emitting species in the tropics migrate to higher latitudes in search of new favorable niches (e.g.,), and if species emitting isoprene, particularly cyanobacteria, become dominant following climate warming, then there will be significant consequences for global atmospheric sulfur and carbon budgets as well as for marine ecology.
